question.title: Open Java Byte Code in readable format and edit it

node.contents: I want to open the Byte code (Java Binaries) generated by Java Compiler using some kind of editor, which allows me to view the byte code (Raw, but human understandable, in the format defined here) & modify things directly in the .class file.

astNode.text: I want to open the Byte code (Java Binaries) generated by Java Compiler using some kind of editor, which allows me to view the byte code (Raw, but human understandable, in the format defined here) & modify things directly in the .class file.

node.contents: I have tried the javap utility. But through javap, I cannot change my .class File, also it doesn't seems to show the raw byte code

astNode.text: I have tried the javap utility. But through javap, I cannot change my .class File, also it doesn't seems to show the raw byte code

node.contents: Also, I have seen de-compiler like JD Decompiler which gives me the code from the .class File. But I am not interested in the source code, I want to view the byte code.

astNode.text: Also, I have seen de-compiler like JD Decompiler which gives me the code from the .class File. But I am not interested in the source code, I want to view the byte code.

node.contents: Also, I have tried GUI editors called dirtyJOE & JBE. This editor is quite a good one and fulfills half of my purpose. I can see various fields in the .class file and edit my .class file as well. But this also seems to be like a translator which decodes the byte code and show it on the UI for easy understanding. It doesn't shows me the raw byte code.

astNode.text: Also, I have tried GUI editors called dirtyJOE & JBE. This editor is quite a good one and fulfills half of my purpose. I can see various fields in the .class file and edit my .class file as well. But this also seems to be like a translator which decodes the byte code and show it on the UI for easy understanding. It doesn't shows me the raw byte code.

node.contents: Is it even possible to go to the raw bytecode?

astNode.text: Is it even possible to go to the raw bytecode?

node.contents: I might sound stupid, but I wanted to confirm this, to understand the Java Compiler and JVM properly.

astNode.text: I might sound stupid, but I wanted to confirm this, to understand the Java Compiler and JVM properly.

node.contents: There are several libraries designed for bytecode manipulation, such as ASM, but I haven't used them so I can't say much about their power or usability.

astNode.text: There are several libraries designed for bytecode manipulation, such as ASM, but I haven't used them so I can't say much about their power or usability.

node.contents: There are also assemblers, which are designed to convert a human readable form into binary class files (I've even written one myself). As far as I know, there aren't any tools to convert class files into assembly format, but I could write one if you're interested.

astNode.text: There are also assemblers, which are designed to convert a human readable form into binary class files (I've even written one myself). As far as I know, there aren't any tools to convert class files into assembly format, but I could write one if you're interested.

node.contents: For simple modifications, you can also just use a hex editor if you know what you're doing. I've edited classes several times in a hex editor before.

astNode.text: For simple modifications, you can also just use a hex editor if you know what you're doing. I've edited classes several times in a hex editor before.

node.contents: @Antimony Thank you for the long reply. ^^

astNode.text: @Antimony Thank you for the long reply. ^^

node.contents: @Antimony There are lots of things you can do with *generated* byte code. Can you provide some examples of where manually editing byte code allows you do things which you can't do in Java so I can see what you mean?

astNode.text: @Antimony There are lots of things you can do with *generated* byte code. Can you provide some examples of where manually editing byte code allows you do things which you can't do in Java so I can see what you mean?

node.contents: This is wrong. There are tons of things you can do in bytecode that you can't do in Java.

astNode.text: This is wrong. There are tons of things you can do in bytecode that you can't do in Java.

node.contents: Off the top of my head: throw checked exceptions without declaring them, catch checked exceptions without declaring them, use identifiers invalid in Java, access fields before constructor call, call different constructors conditionally, do exception handling on constructors, assign final fields more than once or not at all, have a strictfp constructor with nonstrictfp methods, use laxer type checking, throw exceptions from static initializer, use invokedynamic, use subroutines, use unusual control flow, use old super call semantics, use thread monitors, intial values for fields, and many more

astNode.text: Off the top of my head: throw checked exceptions without declaring them, catch checked exceptions without declaring them, use identifiers invalid in Java, access fields before constructor call, call different constructors conditionally, do exception handling on constructors, assign final fields more than once or not at all, have a strictfp constructor with nonstrictfp methods, use laxer type checking, throw exceptions from static initializer, use invokedynamic, use subroutines, use unusual control flow, use old super call semantics, use thread monitors, intial values for fields, and many more

node.contents: Of course when you're doing the things I mentioned, you have to be careful to still follow the VM's type checking rules. But you can access fields defined in the same class before calling the super constructor for instance. Anyway, most of the ones I listed are obscure tricks of interest to writing obfuscators, decompilers, and the like. With the exception of checked exceptions and conditional constructor calls, they're not terribly useful in everyday programming. P.S. Invokedynamic is also useful, since the equivalent code using reflection is slower and much more verbose.

astNode.text: Of course when you're doing the things I mentioned, you have to be careful to still follow the VM's type checking rules. But you can access fields defined in the same class before calling the super constructor for instance. Anyway, most of the ones I listed are obscure tricks of interest to writing obfuscators, decompilers, and the like. With the exception of checked exceptions and conditional constructor calls, they're not terribly useful in everyday programming. P.S. Invokedynamic is also useful, since the equivalent code using reflection is slower and much more verbose.

node.contents: It is possible to dump the raw byte code with javap -v but to get all the information in the class file in a format you can edit I use ASM. The reason you wouldn't use this for editing is;

astNode.text: It is possible to dump the raw byte code with javap -v but to get all the information in the class file in a format you can edit I use ASM. The reason you wouldn't use this for editing is;

node.contents:
• it doesn't allow you to do much that you can't do in Java.
  • it much, much harder to use.
  • you don't get much feed back as to what is wrong if you break it.

astNode.text:
• it doesn't allow you to do much that you can't do in Java.
  • it much, much harder to use.
  • you don't get much feed back as to what is wrong if you break it.

node.contents: Its worth nothing that the byte code is just a compiled for of the Java code which is why they do much the same thing. The JVM is free to optimise it in any number of ways which makes understand the byte code not very useful if you want to understand how the JVM works or the code runs.

astNode.text: Its worth nothing that the byte code is just a compiled for of the Java code which is why they do much the same thing. The JVM is free to optimise it in any number of ways which makes understand the byte code not very useful if you want to understand how the JVM works or the code runs.

node.contents: Thank you to @Antimony for suggested uses for manually written byte code. While some of them are valid they are either fairly advanced or obscure or have an alternative way of achieving the same thing.

node.contents: The byte code does allow different rules for type checking but they are easy to fall foul of with not so helpful VerifyErrors. You could do this but its very hard to get right IMHO.
